did.abstract: The Harmonie Society of Detroit, also known as the Harmonie Club of Detroit, was an organization that allowed German American members of the Detroit community the opportunity to come together and sing traditional German music. The building, which still stands at 267 East Grand River, became a gathering place for German Americans. The collection consists of organizational records, sheet music and songbooks used by the members of the club. Also included are photographs, audio recordings, and programs from German music festivals.

bioghist.p: Founded in 1849, the Harmonie Society of Detroit, also known as the Harmonie Club of Detroit, was organized by German Americans living in the city, who enjoyed singing Lieder, or German poems set to music. As the Society quickly began increasing in size, a clubhouse was built in 1872 as a gathering place for not only members of the organization but German Americans in general. Located at Lafayette and Beaubien, the clubhouse stood until it was destroyed by a fire in 1893. The building was replaced in 1895 at 267 East Grand River where it still stands as a historic site of the state of Michigan.

The Society took great pride in their high musical standards as the organization employed well qualified directors. The club hosted their own men's and women's chorus groups, and also allowed other local groups to use the facilities. While the Society began as an organization of people wanting to sing together, the building became a place of gathering for German Americans in Detroit. The building not only contained practice rooms, but also meeting rooms, a banquet hall, pool tables, a bar, lounges, and much more. The building was a center for German American culture in Detroit during the late 19th century and early 20th century.

As the older generations passed away and the younger generations began moving farther away from the downtown area, membership shrank and the club could no longer afford to own the building. The Harmonie Society continued to meet in various locations, but membership continued to dwindle until it was disbanded in the late 1980s.

scopecontent.p: The materials within the Harmonie Society of Detroit (or, the Harmonie Club) records cover the organizations operations and history. The bulk of the collection consists of sheet music that was used by the Society members.

Organizational records include bylaws, sample financial records, and rosters from the 1920s through the 1950s. Also included are programs and music booklets from a number of Saengerfests, or German singing festivals. A few of these booklets come from festivals held in Michigan, such as in Detroit and Grand Rapids, but a majority comes from other U.S. cities such as New Orleans, Cleveland, Milwaukee, among others.

Collection includes songs in German typically printed in Detroit, or in rare cases, in Germany. Also included are bound books of music for various vocal registers. Some of these books have metal studs to protect their covers from beer or other liquids as they would typically be brought to bars or pubs. In addition to sheet music, collection includes audio recordings of a 1991 performance.

Black-and-white photographs of varying sizes depict Harmonie Society members at formal events, including early group choir photos. Two 1926 photographs are identified as Marcy School in Detroit, Mich; two undated group photographs are of the Harmonie Chorus, with some members identified in the back. Also included in the collection is a scrapbook from the 1940s with newspaper clippings and pictures of the performances and activities of the members.
Located in an oversize box are medals, awards, and other artifacts Collection also includes an oversize banner which was displayed during Society's many performances.
